evidence_span: Most β-quenched Zircaloys possess an approximately random distribution of basal poles (i.e., f_d^c ≈ 0.33) and their growth has been found [5,51] to be very low or zero.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: We have reported test results on recrystallized and cold-worked Zircaloy-2 slab specimens [33] where the growth at 660 to 700 K in the longitudinal, transverse, and thickness directions of the slab appeared to follow the (1-3f) dependence.

evidence_span: We have reported test results on recrystallized and cold-worked Zircaloy-2 slab specimens [33] where the growth at 660 to 700 K in the longitudinal, transverse, and thickness directions of the slab appeared to follow the (1-3f) dependence.

evidence_span: A small amount of cold-work does not change the crystallographic texture (Table 1).

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: after cold-working $1 . 5 \%$ by rolling, the growth of the transverse specimens is in the opposite direction from that of the recrystallized material, at least up to fluences of $1 4 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: For the same material the direction of growth in longitudinal specimens, after an initial positive transient, becomes negative up to fluences of about $5 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$ after which it gradually reverses again.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The effect is even more pronounced in material which is cold-worked $1 . 5 \%$ by pulling in the longitudinal direction in a tensile tester. Here the longitudinal specimens show no evidence of the initial positive transient, and the negative growth rate is much higher than in material deformed $1 . 5 \%$ by rolling.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The negative growth of specimens deformed in tension appears to level off after about $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: A reversal in the direction of irradiation growth at $\Im { 3 0 } \ \mathbf { K }$ has been observed to persist in several lightly cold-worked Zircaloy-2 materials [32].

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Stressrelieving heat treatments at $7 7 0 \ \bf K$ will reduce, but not eliminate, all the transient effects due to irradiation [14].

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Even after $\mathsf { S 0 h }$ of stress relief at $7 7 0 \bf { K }$ the growth strains fall short of the values obtained with recrystallized material (Fig. 3).

evidence_span: the growth after an initial transient attains a low, steady rate which, at temperatures near $\Im { 3 0 } \ \bf K$ ,persists to fluences of at least $1 . 4 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 6 } \ \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$ [32] (Figs. 1 and 2)

evidence_span: The most recent results on recrystallized material to fluences of up to $1 . 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 6 } \ \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$ [21, 29,33] have shown that at irradiation temperatures of $5 5 0 ~ \mathbf { K }$ and above the long term growth does not stay constant but starts to increase towards levels normally observed only in cold-worked materials (Fig. 11).

evidence_span: At 550 to $\bf { 5 8 0 ~ K }$ the onset of the accelerated growth in recrystallized Zircaloy-2 occurred at fluences around 3 to $4 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n m } ^ { - 2 }$
